0.description: When HUFL (High UseFul Load) increases, OT tends to increase due to higher energy consumption demand

1.description: When HULL (High UseLess Load) increases, OT tends to increase due to overall system load pressure

2.description: When MUFL (Middle UseFul Load) increases, OT tends to increase reflecting moderate demand pressure

3.description: When MULL (Middle UseLess Load) increases, OT tends to increase due to system inefficiency

4.description: When LUFL (Low UseFul Load) increases, OT tends to increase reflecting base load demand

5.description: When LULL (Low UseLess Load) increases, OT tends to increase due to system baseline inefficiency

6.description: During peak demand hours (typically morning and evening), OT is generally higher due to increased consumption

7.description: On weekends, OT tends to be lower due to reduced overall activity and demand

8.description: During winter months, OT tends to be higher due to heating demand

9.description: During summer months, OT tends to be higher due to cooling demand
